sectionCopy.name: Clean energy policy
sectionCopy.value: Senegal has set itself a target of 15% renewable energy by 2025, which will be met as soon as 2020. The objective will likely be raised to 18% by 2023, a revision expected to be confirmed by 2H 2019. Clean energy auctions have been held, the most recent being the World Bank-backed 'Scaling Solar' tender. The auction saw 60MW of PV awarded for the rock-bottom price of $0.038/kWh. Further policies include VAT and import duty exemptions for solar panels. For now, VAT waivers are provided on an ad-hoc basis for utility-scale projects pending the release of an equipment list, due for 2H 2019. Finally, a new program will introduce a tariff paid out for all excess energy generated over 20 years for residential biogas and solar.

sectionCopy.name: Clean energy investment
sectionCopy.value: Recent years have seen an influx of renewables investment in Senegal and the Scaling Solar auctions will make a further contribution to helping the sector develop. Bid prices achieved in the auctions are indicative of the sector's growing maturity, even factoring in the power price depression due to the de-risking measures applied to projects. The aforementioned Tabia N'Diaye wind farm, which will be fully commissioned in 2020, was financed by $378 million of U.S. and Danish concessional funding. The sector will likely continue to rely on such development finance in the near-term.

sectionCopy.name: Power prices and LCOEs
sectionCopy.value: Power prices in Senegal have not changed a great deal over past years, but are on a downward trajectory as the government tries to reduce rates. The trend should continue as new renewables projects and domestic gas discoveries drive down production costs, which are higher than elsewhere in the region due to a reliance on costly diesel generation. Early-2019 saw the beginning of a long-awaited harmonization program, through which the private holders of electrification concessions will be compensated so that they can reduce retail rates charged to rural customers, which are higher than those levied by Senelec.

sectionCopy.name: Power market
sectionCopy.value: Only power generation has been liberalized in Senegal, with transmission and distribution remaining vertically-integrated. Independent power producers, such as APR and Aggreko, operate a larger fleet than that of state-owned utility Senelec. The 1.1GW power mix is dominated by oil and diesel, with large hydro, oil, natural gas and coal accounting for the remainder. Additional power is imported from two dams in Mali. A renewables transition is underway, with143MW of solar installed since 2016 and a 158MW wind farm to be commissioned by 2020. However, government support for future additions is likely to be tempered by the discovery of major gas reserves off Senegal's coast, with extraction set to begin in 2022. A pivot back toward thermal energy is also under-way, as the government plans to convert oil plants to dual-fuel and to build several new combined-cycle gas turbines.

sectionCopy.name: Doing business
sectionCopy.value: Senegal's electrification scheme has fallen short of expectations, since being initially hailed as revolutionary upon its launch in 2008. The private concessionary framework assigned ten rural districts to operators, setting out yearly electrification targets in the process. But operators have fallen behind on their goals while charging prohibitive fees to customers. Electrification has progressed steadily despite such system issues. However, with national electrification at 68%, the 2025 universal access target seems ambitious. More generally, Senegal is a dynamic market ' demand is growing fast and the economy is buoyed by a young, skilled workforce.

sectionCopy.name: Barriers
sectionCopy.value: As is common in the region, market-friendly policies are implemented at a slow rate ' retail tariff harmonization and clarity on VAT-exempt equipment are just two areas where implementation has been delayed. Off-grid developers have bemoaned the fact that import duty waivers do not apply to their products, pushing up project costs. However, developers have praised the fact that, despite lengthy bureaucratic processes, the authorities have been efficient when it comes to permitting projects. Senelec is said to pay IPPs in a timely manner and the utility is in better financial health than its regional peers, having restructured its finances while introducing a successful prepayment scheme.
